thread.title: DA: Case of woman shot in the face was gang violence
thread.title_full: DA: Case of woman shot in the face was gang violence - KPTV - FOX 12

author: Kati Weis, FOX10 News Reporter
title: DA: Case of woman shot in the face was gang violence
text:
MOBILE, AL (WALA) - "This is gang activity," Mobile County Assistant District Attorney Keith Blackwood told FOX10 News Monday, October 19, about an attempted carjacking in Midtown back in June.
"These juveniles were associated together in a gang, they identify themselves as being in that gang, together," said Blackwood. "They were together, out and about to commit crimes in the name of this gang."
FOX10 News asked Blackwood if he was able to disclose the name of the gang, but he responded, "I'm not able now, it's a completely inappropriate name."
Maria Williamson, 26, was sitting at a stoplight at the corner of Monterey and Dauphin Streets one night in June, when police said a group of teens approached her vehicle, shot her in the eye, and tried to get in her car. Williamson was able to drive away, but lost her eye.
"They were out together in the middle of the night to commit crimes, and this is the result of it, a poor innocent woman gets shot in the face when she's on her way home from work," said Blackwood.
Youth judge rules shooter needs mental evaluation
A court hearing was also held Monday, October 19, at Strickland Youth Center, where the alleged shooter's defense attorney asked the judge to grant the juvenile an updated mental evaluation, even though the D.A.'s office said the teen has already had a couple mental evaluations in the past.
According to Blackwood, the 15-year-old alleged shooter will get the mental evaluation before a youth judge will determine whether or not he should be charged as an adult in the case of the attempted carjacking.
"They are looking for the mental capacity at the time of the defense, and the ability to stand trial," said Blackwood about the mental evaluation.
The alleged shooter will face a Strickland judge again in November, after the mental evaluation has been completed, for the judge to decide whether or not he should be prosecuted as an adult.
Other juvenile "gang members" facing charges
Meanwhile, two other juveniles involved in the crime were granted youth status at Monday's hearing, which means those two will be prosecuted at Strickland Youth Center, and will not be charged as adults.
An official with the D.A.'s office told FOX10 News those two teens are 14 and 15-years-old.
Of the eight teens allegedly involved in the crime, four 15-year-old boys and one 14-year-old will be prosecuted in the juvenile system, according to Blackwood.
However, law enforcement is still looking for a 13-year-old, who officials said was also involved in the attempted carjacking.
"If he were with his parents or in school, we would know where he is, but right now we do not know where he is," said Blackwood about the 13-year-old still at large.
When that juvenile is taken into custody, he will also face the same charges as the others charged: attempted murder, first degree robbery and shooting into an occupied vehicle.
Only one alleged gang member to face adult charges, so far
Currently, only one teen faces adult prosecution. Isaiah Kelly, 16, has also been charged with attempted murder, first degree robbery, and shooting into an occupied vehicle.
In a "perp walk" at Mobile Police Headquarters, reporters asked why he was in handcuffs, to which Kelly responded, "I was there."
Officials said the reason Kelly has been charged as an adult is because if a child commits a crime with a weapon at the age of 16, they bypass the juvenile system entirely and are treated as an adult.
Warrants issued for the arrest of witnesses
According to Blackwood, the D.A.'s office has issued warrants for the arrest of some witnesses in the case, who failed to show up after being served subpoenas for their testimony.
Blackwood said the witnesses did not see the crime first-hand, but are "witnesses in another capacity."
